customer_addr:
1335 Arboretum Dr
Suite A
Redding, CA 96003

citations.narrative:
In the large Lory walk in aviary, the top of 2 bird cages housing the single lory, was covered with pieces of plastic
welcome matting that had been attached upside down. The exposed under part of the mats had a thin film of rubber
padding that the birds were observed picking small chunks off. The enclosures in the shelter building adjacent to the
aviary also had the flipped over mats with birds chewing on the exposed rubber padding. The top of the metal cover
around an air unit had a few large pieces of flaking and chipped paint and bird droppings around it. There was also a
small area of concrete window ledge, that was not painted and had small pieces of concrete chipped away. Ingesting
plastic matting, peeling paint or chipping concrete could cause injury to the birds. The primary enclosure must be
constructed and maintained in good repair to protect the bird from injury.
Correct by: 10/25/2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the facility does provide species appropriate enrichment within the enclosures, the facility did not have a
documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian species as required by the
Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending
veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint,
and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional standards.
Correct by: 10/5/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility Manager.
Additional Inspectors:
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In the large Lory walk in aviary, the top of 2 bird cages housing the single lory, was covered with pieces of plastic 
welcome matting that had been attached upside down. The exposed under part of the mats had a thin film of rubber 
padding that the birds were observed picking small chunks off. The enclosures in the shelter building adjacent to the 
aviary also had the flipped over mats with birds chewing on the exposed rubber padding. The top of the metal cover 
around an air unit had a few large pieces of flaking and chipped paint and bird droppings around it. There was also a 
small area of concrete window ledge, that was not painted and had small pieces of concrete chipped away. Ingesting 
plastic matting, peeling paint or chipping concrete could cause injury to the birds. The primary enclosure must be 
constructed and maintained in good repair to protect the bird from injury. 
 
Correct by: 10/25/2023 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the facility does provide species appropriate enrichment within the enclosures, the facility did not have a 
documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian species as required by the 
Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental 
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending 
veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint, 
and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional standards. 
 
Correct by: 10/5/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility Manager.
